user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ignore_sigpipe:
```c
static void
ignore_sigpipe (void)
{
  struct sigaction oldsig;
  struct sigaction sig;

  sig.sa_handler = &catcher;
  sigemptyset (&sig.sa_mask);
#ifdef SA_INTERRUPT
  sig.sa_flags = SA_INTERRUPT;  /* SunOS */
#else
  sig.sa_flags = SA_RESTART;
#endif
  if (0 != sigaction (SIGPIPE, &sig, &oldsig))
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to install SIGPIPE handler: %s\n", strerror (errno));
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strerror (errno)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The call strerror(errno) returns a char * from the C library; the user code does not declare a pointer type here nor attempt to modify the returned string — it is passed read-only to fprintf. Rule 8.13 concerns pointer declarations in user code and encouraging const qualification where possible; you cannot change the library prototype. (If you had declared a non-const pointer to hold the result and then modified the buffer, that would be a violation scenario.)
